name: Kepler-195
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-195 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-195 is a star with 0.675 times the mass of the Sun, and 0.78 times its radius. It is located 2167.21 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-195 is known to have 2 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-195 b

Kepler-195 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.08 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 8.31 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-195.

The mass of Kepler-195 b is 5.26 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-195 b is 2.03 that of Earth. At 5.26 Earth masses, Kepler-195 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-195 c

Kepler-195 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.20 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 34.10 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-195.

The mass of Kepler-195 c is 2.74 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-195 c is 1.55 that of Earth. At 2.74 Earth masses, Kepler-195 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-195, which contains 2 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
